Calculate Fetch Lengths from Points Using Radiating Bearings

calculate_fetch.Rd

This function generates rays from input points at specified angular intervals, clips them to land polygons, and calculates the effective fetch length (open-water distance) for each direction. Optionally runs in parallel.

Usage

calculate_fetch(
  points,
  degrees,
  fetch = 5000,
  land,
  parallel = TRUE,
  cores = 9
)

Arguments

points

An sf object of type POINT with a column id.

degrees

Numeric. Angular spacing between bearings (e.g., 7.5, 10).

fetch

Numeric. Maximum fetch distance in meters. Default is 5000.

land

An sf object representing land polygons (must overlap rays).

parallel

Logical. If TRUE, uses furrr::future_map_dfr for parallel execution.

cores

Integer. Number of cores to use if parallel = TRUE.

Value

An sf object with id, bearing, segment_id, geometry, and length_km columns.

Details

  • Rays are generated at degrees intervals around the compass.

  • Rays are clipped by land polygons to estimate open-water fetch.

  • Fetch is measured as the remaining ray segment length after clipping land.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
  future::plan(multisession, workers = 4)
  fetch_data <- calculate_fetch(my_points, degrees = 10, fetch = 5000, land = gbr_land, parallel = TRUE)
} # }
